step1.content: hey there and welcome to no recipe required tonight I've got a stuffed mushroom dish for now I'm usually not crazy about stuffed mushrooms because I find the mushroom is a little too beefy meaty and frankly me I was a little undercooked and a little water I've got a little trick to take care of that we're gonna get cooking we're gonna get the mushrooms cook down a little bit more or make an awesome filling with some of the mushroom itself some pine nuts of bread crumbs some Parmesan cheese it's absolutely killer let's go ahead and get started okay I've got some cremini mushrooms here and if you are if you're ever gonna do stuff in mushroom you need to be able to follow out a mushroom so on these what I like to use because they've got a nice you know kind of stem that's easy to pull out at a good area in there easiest thing to do if the stem pops out easily this one's not popping out really easily then you know sometimes they just break off you're good to go otherwise you can take a knife here and just go right around the stem I kind of actually hold it on the blade to get full control and just turn it hold the knife still turn the mushroom and you can pop that stem right out you can certainly just go right there put a little stuffing in there or you can then take a spoon and just kind of scrape out the insides and the gills out of the shroom and it's dump those right out on the on the cutting board discard them not a whole lot of use for the gills the stems you can cut off throwing the throw on your stuffing

step1.content: hi guys I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode of Laura in the kitchen I want to show you how I make my shot I call them like my creamy sausage stuffed mushrooms they are absolutely insanely good you're gonna love them and they're really great like lower like a low carb option for your Easter table I've been getting a lot of messages on Instagram to share just a couple of like low carb options for your Easter menu so I feel this would be really great and you can make them into an entree if you want to by just using bigger mushrooms like a portobello mushroom and that would be fantastic but these are gonna be great with a little bit of arugula and fennel salad for either an entree a side dish a starter whatever you fancy let me when you're through the list of in Greensborough beg you need some mushrooms these are just white button mushrooms that I prepped and I'll show you one in just a second I've got a four blend cheese here mozzarella Asiago provolone and lots of freshly grated parm these are the stems from those mushrooms that I just finely chopped onion garlic parsley a little cream cheese Italian sausage salt and a little bit of olive oil now I'm gonna show you how I prepped the mushrooms just to give you an idea of how I did all of them so I just take out the stem and you take the stem and you give it a nice little chopper Roux because this is perfectly edible it's not too hard it's not too tough it's perfect and just take a little teeny tiny teaspoon right and this doesn't have to be pretty because these are gonna be covered so you won't see it but I kind of just get rid of all the center bits so I've got a nice amount of surface area here for the stuffing and that's it I just kind of took a damp paper towel to clean each one and they're good to go
step1.label: Preparation of Mushrooms
step1.explanation: This segment describes the initial preparation of the mushrooms, including the removal of stems and cleaning, which aligns with the step of preparing mushrooms for stuffing.

step3.content: once the oil is hot add in your onion and let it fry for a bit once the onion starts looking blazing let's add the mushroom give it a good stir and fry this for about a minute then crushing your garlic make sure not to over fry your garlic otherwise it won't become bitter starting to smell really really nice at this point it's optional to season your mushrooms I'm just going to season them with some and a little bit of salt now let's add in the key beans and the corn and fry that for about three to four minutes to make it a better greener you can sprinkle a little bit of chives in there or you can leave them all as decoration that's all up to you at this point you can turn up the fire now let's add a good tablespoon of sour cream and of course it depends how spicy you want it squeeze a good amount of sriracha sauce on top let's mix everything up and there you go the filling is done

step5.content: Begin by melting the butter in a large pan. Once the butter is melted, add in the onions, the bacon or in my case, my salami and the garlic. Sauté gently until the onions become soft. After about 5 minutes or so, gentle sautéing, the onion should be nice and soft. I'll turn off the heat. Add in all the remaining ingredients: the mushrooms, the breadcrumbs and the rosemary. Give it all a good mix. When everything is nicely mixed, it's ready for use!
step5.label: Baking or Cooking
step5.explanation: This segment covers the cooking process of the stuffing mixture, starting with melting butter and sautéing the onions and other ingredients until everything is mixed and ready for use.

step5.content: So I'm gonna put these in a preheated 400 degree oven and bake 'em for 20 to 25 minutes, until the mushrooms are nice and soft and kind of shrively and the tops are brown and toasty and everything inside is all melty and yummy and gooey.
step5.label: Baking or Cooking
step5.explanation: This part of the narration outlines the cooking process, specifically baking the stuffed mushrooms, which is essential for completing the dish.

step5.explanation: Describes the baking process of the stuffing, including times and methods, fitting the baking or cooking step.
